column2: Karuk: uuth) is the principal city and county seat of Humboldt County in the Redwood Empire region of California. The city is located on U.S. Route 101 on the shores of Humboldt Bay
column3: 270 miles (435 km) north of San Francisco and 100 miles (161 km) south of the Oregon border. At the 2010 census

column1: Eureka's Pacific coastal location on Humboldt Bay
column2: adjacent to abundant redwood forests
column3: provided the reason for settlement of this 19th-century seaport town. Before the arrival of Euro-American settlers

column8: the area was occupied by indigenous peoples.

column1: The Wiyot people lived in Jaroujiji (Wiyot: "where you sit and rest")
column2: now known as Eureka
column3: for thousands of years before European arrival. They are the farthest-southwest people whose language has Algic roots. Their traditional coastal homeland ranged from the lower Mad River through Humboldt Bay and south along the lower basin of the Eel River. The Wiyot are particularly known for their basketry and fishery management. An extensive collection of intricate basketry of the area's indigenous groups exists in the Clarke Historical Museum in Old Town Eureka.

column2: Eureka High School has the largest Yurok language program in California.

European exploration of the coast of what would become northern California repeatedly missed definitively locating Humboldt Bay because of a combination of geographic features and weather conditions which concealed the narrow bay entrance from view. Despite a well-documented 1806 sighting by Russian explorers
column3: the bay was not definitively known by Europeans until an 1849 overland exploration provided a reliable accounting of the exact location of what is the second largest bay in California. The timing of this discovery led to the May 13
column5: founding of the settlement of Eureka on its shore by the Union and Mendocino Exploring (development) companies.

column1: After the primary California Gold Rush in the Sierras
column2: Humboldt Bay was settled with the intent of providing a convenient alternative to the long overland route from Sacramento to supply miners on the Trinity
column3: Klamath and Salmon Rivers where gold had been discovered. Though the ideal location on Humboldt Bay adjacent to naturally deeper shipping channels ultimately guaranteed Eureka's development as the primary city on the bay
column4: Arcata's proximity to developing supply lines to inland gold mines ensured supremacy over Eureka through 1856."Eureka" received its name from a Greek word meaning "I have found it!" This exuberant statement of successful (or hopeful) gold rush miners is also the official motto of the State of California. Eureka is the only U.S. location to use the same seal as the state for its seal.

column1: The first Europeans venturing into Humboldt Bay encountered the indigenous Wiyot. After 1850
column2: Americans ultimately overwhelmed the Wiyot
column3: whose maximum population before the Europeans was in the hundreds in the area of what would become the county's primary city. But in almost every case
column4: settlers ultimately cut off access to ancestral sources of food in addition to the outright theft of land
column5: despite efforts of some U.S. Government and military officials to assist the native peoples or at least maintain peace. Fort Humboldt was established on January 30
column7: by the U.S. Army as a buffer between Native Americans
column8: gold-seekers and settlers
column9: commanded by Brevet Lieutenant Colonel Robert C. Buchanan of the U.S. 4th Infantry Regiment. The 1860 Wiyot Massacre took place on Indian Island in the spring of 1860
column10: committed by a group of locals
column11: thought to be primarily Eureka businessmen. (The male Wiyot tribal members had left the Island during their annual New Year ritual and the vigilantes killed as many as 250 children
column13: and elderly indians) Major Gabriel J. Rains
column14: Commanding Officer of Fort Humboldt at the time
column15: reported to his commanding officer that a local group of vigilantes had resolved to "kill every peaceable Indian – man

column1: Eureka's first post office opened in 1853 just as the town began to carve its grid plan into the edge of a forest it would ultimately consume to feed the building of San Francisco and beyond. Many of the first immigrants who arrived as prospectors were also lumbermen
column2: and the vast potential for industry on the bay was soon realized
column3: especially as many hopeful gold miners realized the difficulty and infrequency of striking it rich in the mines. By 1854
column4: after only four years since the founding
column5: seven of nine mills processing timber into marketable lumber on Humboldt Bay were within Eureka. A year later 140 lumber schooners operated in and out of Humboldt Bay moving lumber from the mills to booming cities along the Pacific coast. By the time the charter for Eureka was granted in 1856
column6: busy mills inside the city had a daily production capacity of 220
column7: 000 board feet. This level of production
column8: which would grow significantly and continue for more than a century
column9: secured Eureka as the "timber capital" of California. Eureka was at the apex of rapid growth of the lumber industry because of its location between huge coast redwood forests and its control of the primary port facilities. Loggers brought the enormous redwood trees down. Dozens of movable narrow gauge railroads brought trainloads of logs and finished lumber products to the main rail line
column10: which led directly to Eureka's wharf and waiting schooners. By the 1880s
column11: railroads eventually brought the production of hundreds of mills throughout the region to Eureka
column12: primarily for shipment through its port. After the early 1900s
column13: shipment of products occurred by trucks
column17: and other points in the region
column18: but Eureka remained the busy center of all this activity for over 120 years. These factors and others made Eureka a significant city in early California state history.

column1: A bustling commercial district with ornate Victorian style buildings rose in proximity to the waterfront
column2: reflecting the great prosperity experienced during this era. Hundreds of these Victorian homes remain today
column3: of which many are totally restored and a few have always remained in their original elegance and splendor. The representation of these homes in Eureka grouped with those in nearby Arcata and the Victorian village of Ferndale are of considerable importance to the overall development of Victorian architecture built in the nation. The magnificent Carson Mansion on 2nd and M Streets
column4: is perhaps the most spectacular Victorian in the nation. The home was built between 1884 and 1886 by renowned 19th-century architects Newsom and Newsom for lumber baron William M. Carson. This project was designed to keep mill workers and expert craftsman busy during a slow period in the industry. Old Town Eureka
column5: the original downtown center of this busy city in the 19th century
column6: has been restored and has become a lively arts center. The Old Town area has been declared an Historic District by the National Register of Historic Places. The district is made up of over 150 buildings
column7: which in total represents much of Eureka's original 19th-century core commercial center. This nexus of culture behind the redwood curtain still contains much of its Victorian architecture
column8: which
column9: if not maintained for original use as commercial buildings or homes
column10: have been transformed into scores of unique lodgings
column11: restaurants
column12: and small shops featuring a burgeoning cottage industry of hand-made creations from glass ware to wood-burning stoves and a large variety of art created locally.

In 1858 the first of many ships built in Eureka was launched beginning an industry that spanned scores of years. The bay is also the site of the west coast's largest oyster farming operations

Eureka is the home port to more than 100 fishing vessels (with an all-time high of over 400 in 1981) in two modern marinas which can berth approximately 400 boats within the city limits and at least 50 more in nearby Fields Landing

column1: Rising emigration from China in the late 19th century sparked conflict between white settlers and immigrants
column2: which ultimately led to the Chinese Exclusion Act. Economic downturns resulting in competition for jobs led to violent actions against Chinese immigrants
column3: especially on the Pacific coast. In February 1885
column4: the racial tension in Eureka intensified when Eureka City Councilman David Kendall was caught in the crossfire of two rival Chinese gangs and killed. This led to the convening of 600 Eureka men and resulted in the forcible permanent expulsion of all 480 Chinese residents of Eureka's Chinatown.Among those who guarded the city jail during the height of the sinophobic tension was James Gillett
column5: who went on to become Governor of California. The anti-Chinese ordinance was repealed in 1959.

column1: === Queen City of the Ultimate West ===

Completion of the Northwestern Pacific Railroad in 1914 provided the local lumber industry with an alternative to ships for transport of its millions of board feet of lumber to reach markets in San Francisco and beyond. It also provided the first safe land route between San Francisco and Eureka for people to venture to the Redwood Empire. As a result
column2: Eureka's population of 7
column3: 300 swelled to 15
column4: 000 within ten years. By 1922 the Redwood Highway was completed
column5: providing for the first reliable
column6: direct overland route for automobiles from San Francisco. By 1931 the Eureka Street Railway operated fifteen streetcars over twelve miles of track. Eureka's transportation connection to the "outside" world had changed dramatically after more than half a century of stage rides or treacherous steamship passage through the Humboldt Bar and on the Pacific Ocean to San Francisco. The building of the Eureka Inn coincided with the opening of the new road to San Francisco. As a result of immense civic pride during this early 20th-century era of expansion
column7: Eureka officially nicknamed itself "Queen City of the Ultimate West." The tourism industry
column8: lodging to support it
column9: and related marketing had been born.

column1: The timber economy of Eureka is part of the Pacific Northwest timber economy which rises and falls with boom and bust economic times. In Eureka
column2: both the timber industry and commercial fishing declined after the Second World War.The Columbus Day Storm of 1962 downed trees and caused a surplus in the domestic timber market
column3: which caused increased shipping to foreign markets. The log trade with Japan and other Pacific Rim nations increased. Despite many rumors to the contrary
column4: little of this wood returned to U.S. markets. In 1989
column5: the U.S. changed log export laws permitting lower cost timber from public lands to be exported as raw logs overseas to help balance the federal budget.After 1990
column6: the global log market declined
column7: and exports fell at the same time as Pacific Northwest log prices increased; leading buyers to seek less expensive logs from Canada and the southern United States. However
column8: debate continues between four stakeholders: timber owners
column9: domestic processors
column10: consumers and communities on the impact of log export on the local economy.

column2: timber harvest peaked in 1997. The local timber market was also affected by the Pacific Lumber Company hostile takeover and ultimate bankruptcy.Local fisheries expanded through the 1970s and early 1980s. During the 1970s
column3: Eureka fishermen landed more than half of the fish and shellfish produced and consumed in California. In 2010 between 100 and 120 commercial fishing vessels listed Eureka as homeport. The highest landings of all species were 36.9 million pounds (16.7 million kg) in 1981 while the lowest were in 2001 with 9.4 million pounds (4.3 million kg).After 1990 regulatory
column4: economic
column5: and other events led to a contraction of the local commercial fleet. In 1991
column6: the Woodley Island marina opened
column7: providing docking facilities for much of Eureka's commercial and recreational fleet. Many species are considered to be overfished. Recreational fishing has increased over time. Fifty percent of recreational fishermen using local boats are tourists from outside the area.Commercial Pacific oyster aquaculture in Humboldt Bay produced an average of 7
column9: 000 pounds (3
column11: 000 kg) of oysters from 1956 to 1965 an average of 844
column16: 000 kg) were harvested. Oysters and oyster seed continue to be exported from Humboldt Bay. The value of the oysters and spawn is more than $6 million per year. Consolidation of buyers and landing facilities resulted in local vulnerability to unexpected events
column17: leading the City to obtain grant funding for and complete the Fishermen's Terminal on the waterfront which will provide fish handling

column1: The area regularly experiences large earthquakes as it is situated on the southern end the Cascadia subduction zone and near the San Andreas Fault
column2: which interface around the Mendocino Triple Junction. On January 9
column4: a 6.5 magnitude earthquake occurred about 33 miles (53 km) off shore from Eureka. After two seconds
column5: it became a violent "jumper"
column6: making objects fly; the mostly vertical shocks from the ground led to broken windows in shops
column7: overturned shelving in homes and stores
column8: and damage to architectural detail on a number of historic buildings. Local hospitals treated mostly minor related injuries
column9: and electrical power was out over a large area. Numerous natural gas leaks occurred
column10: but no fires resulted. This was the largest recent earthquake since the April 25–26
column11: 1992 sequence. It was followed on February 4
column13: by a magnitude 5.9 earthquake which struck about 35 miles (56 km) northwest of the community of Petrolia and nearly 50 miles (80 km) west of Eureka. The shaking was felt within a 150-mile (240 km) radius
column14: as far north as southern Oregon and as far south as Sonoma County. The largest recorded in the area was the 7.2 Mw  event on November 8
column15: 1980. The larger earthquakes can pose a tsunami threat to coastal areas.

column1: Eureka is situated within California's Redwood Empire region which includes Pacific Ocean coast
column2: Humboldt Bay

column1: The city marina is on one of three islands at a narrow point on the 13-mile-long (21 km) bay and increases in elevation slightly as it spreads north
column2: south
column3: and especially to the east. The city gently encroaches at least two miles (3.2 km) eastward into primarily Redwood and Douglas-fir second growth forests. The city has a traditional grid that generally radiates toward the points of the compass. Most post-1970 houses were built in formerly clear cut forested areas.

column1: The transition between the official city limits and smaller unincorporated areas is mostly not discernible. Eastern areas including secluded developments on a golf course among or in close proximity to extensive second-growth forest have more recently developed. These new houses were built as a result of the Eureka Community Plan of 1995 in attempt to bring locals close to centers of recreation and encourage community interaction. The city then gives way to hills and mountains of the rugged coast range
column2: which quickly exceed 2
column3: 000 feet (610 m) in elevation.

column1: The economic base of the city was founded on timber and fishing and supplying gold mining efforts inland. Gold mining diminished quickly in the early years
column2: and activities of timber and fishing have also diminished
column3: especially in the latter decades of the twentieth century. Today
column4: the major industries are tourism
column5: timber (in value)
column6: and healthcare and services (in number of jobs). Major employers today in Eureka include the following governmental entities: College of the Redwoods
column7: The County of Humboldt
column8: and the Humboldt County Office of Education. St. Joseph Hospital is the largest private employer in Eureka.

column1: The City of Eureka has a mayor-council system of governance. Primary power lies with the five council members
column2: divided up into five wards. The mayor has the power to appoint
column3: as well as ceremonial duties
column4: though the job includes presiding over council meetings
column5: and meeting visiting dignitaries. Official city business is administered by the Office of the City Manager. The Eureka City Council regularly meets on the 1st and 3rd Tuesdays of the month at 5:30 pm for closed session
column6: and 6:30 pm for open session. Open sessions are open to the public.

column1: U.S. Route 101 is the major north and south highway
column2: which connects Eureka to the rest of the North Coast region. The highway connects to Oregon
column3: located approximately 100 miles (161 km) to the north
column4: and San Francisco
column5: over 250 miles (402 km) to the south. The highway follows city streets through the city
column6: with flow and cross-traffic controlled by traffic signals. Highway 101 enters Eureka from the south as Broadway. As it reaches the downtown area
column7: it splits into a one-way couplet composed of 4th Street and 5th Street. On the north side of the city
column8: northbound and southbound rejoin at the northeast side before the highway becomes a restricted (safety corridor) expressway (to Arcata and points beyond) as double bridges cross the Eureka Slough (mouth of the Freshwater Creek). State Route 255 is an alternate route of U.S. 101 between Eureka and the nearby city of Arcata
column9: running along the western shore of Humboldt Bay. It begins in the downtown area at U.S. 101 and proceeds north along R Street towards the Samoa Bridge and the community of Samoa. State Route 299 (formerly U.S. Route 299) connects to U.S. Route 101 at the northern end of Arcata. Route 299 begins at that point and extends easterly to serve as the major traffic artery to the east for Eureka.

column1: Eureka's full service airport is the Arcata-Eureka Airport
column2: located 15 miles (24 km) north in McKinleyville. This airport has one airline
column3: United Airlines
column4: and connects to San Francisco and Los Angeles
column5: CA. Murray Field and Eureka Municipal Airport are general aviation airports for private and charter air service. Both are located adjacent to Humboldt Bay. Kneeland Airport
column6: at 2
column7: 737 feet (834 m) elevation
column8: is a general aviation airport that provides an option for pilots choosing to land when the prevalent marine layer is affecting airports nearer sea level.

column1: The Humboldt Bay Harbor Recreation & Conservation District manages the resources of Humboldt Bay and its environs
column2: including the deep water port. The port is located directly west of the city and is serviced across the bay in the community of Samoa. In addition to two deep water channel docks for large ships
column3: several modern small craft marinas are available for private use
column4: with a total capacity of more than 400 boats.

column1: Public bus transportation services within Eureka are provided by the Eureka Transit Service. The Redwood Transit System provides bus transportation through Eureka and connects to major towns and places outside the city
column2: including educational institutions. Dial-A-Ride service is available through an application process.

column1: Amtrak provides Thruway Bus service to Eureka at its unstaffed bus stop. The bus service connects passengers from the northernmost coastal train station in Martinez
column2: California
column3: and continues to southern Oregon.

column1: Greyhound provides bus service to San Francisco from Eureka. Tickets may be purchased online or at the nearest full service station in Arcata.

Eureka residents are served by Pacific Gas and Electric Company. Some reserves of natural gas are located south of the city. These and other fuels help power the Humboldt Bay Power Plant (which includes the defunct Humboldt Bay Nuclear Power Plant). In 2010
column2: the cogeneration plant increased its capacity from 130 MW to 163 MW.

column1: The City of Eureka is the largest of the local water districts supplied by the Humboldt Bay Municipal Water District. The entire region is one of the few places in California that has historically enjoyed a significant surplus of water. The reduction in major forest products manufacturing in recent decades has left the area with a 45 MGD surplus of industrial water.
Eureka is the regional center for healthcare. The city is served by St. Joseph Hospital
column2: which is the largest medical acute care hospital north of the San Francisco Bay Area on the California Coast. The hospital was the first opened in 1920 and was operated by the Sisters of Saint Joseph of Orange until 2016. The facility is composed of two parts: a main campus contains the acute care facility and a nearby second site
column3: the former General Hospital Campus
column4: which contains a rehabilitation facility and a skilled nursing site.

column2: the hospital completed required earthquake safety standards upgrades. The new primary wing contains surgical suites
column3: intensive care
column4: 24-hour emergency care
column5: as well as new and enlarged patient rooms for those requiring care beyond short stay or outpatient procedures
column6: assisted living facilities
column7: skilled nursing facilities
column8: surgery centers
column9: and radiology (including MRI) facilities.In June 2016
column10: The California Attorney General's office approved merging the St. Joseph Health system and the Providence Health and Services which includes St. Joseph's in Eureka
column11: which becomes part of the third-largest non-profit health system in the nation. The merger raises local and regional concerns about health care.Eureka is also the site of the only comprehensive private and county operated mental health emergency and hospitalization facilities north of San Francisco within California. Most of the doctors for the many medical specialties available on the far North Coast are located in or near Eureka
column12: which also has the only oncology program and dialysis clinic in the region.

column1: Institutions of higher learning include the College of the Redwoods and Humboldt State University in Arcata. College of the Redwoods manages a downtown satellite campus as well.

column1: The North Coast's primary shopping facility
column2: the Bayshore Mall
column3: is the largest north of the San Francisco Bay Area on the California coast. The mall features over 70 stores
column4: which is anchored by Kohl's and Walmart. TJ Maxx and Ulta opened in 2013. Other major shopping areas and centers include Henderson Center
column5: the Eureka Mall

column1: Eureka is one of California's historic landmarks. The California State Historical marker
column3: designating Eureka
column4: is located in Old Town
column5: one of the nation's best preserved original Victorian era commercial districts. The city was voted as the No. 1 best small art town in John Villani's book "The 100 Best Small Art Towns in America." Eureka hosts the region's largest monthly cultural and arts event
column6: "Arts' Alive!" on the first Saturday of each month. More than 80 Eureka business and local galleries open their doors to the public. Often local cuisine and beverages accompany live performances by acclaimed regional bands and other types of performance art. The downtown Eureka area is also decorated with many murals.Theater offerings include year-round productions from several various theater groups including the North Coast Repertory Theater
column7: the Redwood Curtain Theatre
column8: and the Eureka Theater. Various events occur throughout the year at the Redwood Acres Fairgrounds. Museums include the Clarke Historical Museum
column9: the Humboldt Bay Maritime Museum
column10: the Morris Graves Museum of Art
column11: HSU First Street Gallery
column13: the Fort Humboldt State Historic Park and the Blue Ox Millworks and Historic Park.

column1: Because of northern isolation and unfavorable economic conditions in the latter part of the twentieth century
column2: much of the post-war redevelopment and urban renewal that other cities experienced did not occur in Eureka. As a result
column3: Eureka has hundreds of examples of 19th- and early 20th-century architecture and historic districts.

column1: The original Queen Anne-style Murphy home in San Francisco was completely destroyed by the fire resulting from the 1906 San Francisco earthquake. Mark Carter found the blueprints for the home in an antique store and rebuilt the structure
column2: but in Eureka; it is now the Carter House Inn.Approximately 16% of the city's structures are cataloged as important historical structures
column3: with many of those attaining the status of state and national significance in terms of a particular structure's importance in relationship to the body of surviving examples of the architectural style attributed to its construction and related detail. Thirteen distinct districts have been identified which meet the criteria for the National Register of Historic Places. Among them are the 2nd Street District (10 buildings)
column4: 15th Street district (13 buildings) and the O Street district (43 buildings). Hillsdale Street
column5: a popular and well-preserved district
column6: contains 17 buildings of historic interest. In all
column7: some 1
column8: 500 buildings have been recognized as qualifying for the National Register. The Eureka Heritage Society
column9: a local architectural preservation group founded in 1973
column10: has been instrumental in protecting and preserving many of Eureka's fine Victorians.

column2: situated on more than 67 acres (270
column3: 000 m2) of mature second-growth Redwood forest
column4: includes Eureka's largest public playground and a duck pond
column5: in addition to meticulously kept gardens and examples of the area's many varieties of rhododendron bushes. The City of Eureka Recreation Department manages 13 playgrounds
column6: including Cooper Gulch
column7: which is 33 acres (13 ha)
column8: and many ball fields as well as tennis courts and others
column9: including basketball and soccer. Other parks in or near Eureka include the Humboldt Botanical Garden and the Humboldt Bay National Wildlife Refuge
column10: and the Eureka Marsh
column11: an accessible protected marsh between the Bayshore Mall and Humboldt Bay. There is a modern boardwalk along the city's waterfront.
